terms.definition: The systematic procedure of disconnecting and securing a system to ensure it is de-energised, different from simple switching because it includes physical locking and verification to prevent accidental re-energisation.

A dedicated instrument used to confirm the absence of voltage that must meet specific safety standards, different from a multimeter because it lacks internal fuses or user-selectable ranges that could lead to a false-negative reading.

A device that generates a known voltage to verify that a test instrument is working correctly, which must be used both before and after checking for dead to ensure the indicator has not failed during the test.
The safety procedure of securing an isolation point with a physical lock and warning tag to ensure that only the authorized person performing the work can re-energise the system.

The specific stage of safe isolation where a verified indicator is used to confirm no hazardous voltage exists between all conductors and earth, not to be confused with simply checking for a loss of function in a device.

content.title: The Safe Isolation Sequence
content.content:
### In this lesson
- You will learn the systematic steps required to achieve a safe working environment on electrical systems.
- This procedure is applied before any work begins to ensure conductors are de-energised and cannot be switched back on.
- Key takeaways include the correct order of the JIB workflow, the role of physical locking, and the verification of dead circuits.

**What this is**
**Safe Isolation** is a formal, multi-step procedure used to disconnect and secure an electrical system. Unlike simple switching, which merely turns a device off, **Safe Isolation** involves physical security and verified testing. It ensures that the point of work is completely disconnected from the supply and that no unauthorized person can re-energise the circuit while work is in progress. It relies on a combination of mechanical locks and electrical verification using specialized tools.

**Why it matters**
Electricity is often invisible and silent. Without a rigorous sequence, a worker might assume a circuit is off when it is actually being fed from an alternative source or a mislabelled breaker. Furthermore, in a busy environment, another person might see a switch in the 'off' position and flip it back 'on' to restore power to their own area, unknowingly endangering the person working on that circuit. This sequence provides the evidence and security needed to work with confidence.

**Key facts / rules**
- Always identify the correct source of supply before attempting isolation.
- The procedure must follow a logical sequence to ensure no steps are missed.
- **Lock-out Tag-out (LOTO)** must be used to physically prevent the operation of the isolation device.
- Only the person performing the work should hold the key to the isolation lock.
- Verification must be performed at the specific point where work will take place.
- A circuit is only considered safe once it has been proven dead and the tester has been re-verified.

**How to do it**
To perform the JIB-style safe isolation workflow, follow these steps in order. First, identify the circuit or equipment that requires isolation. Second, coordinate with the site users to ensure the disconnection will not cause secondary hazards. Third, operate the isolation device (such as a main switch or circuit breaker) to the 'off' position. Fourth, apply **Lock-out Tag-out (LOTO)** by placing a physical lock on the device and attaching a warning tag. 

Fifth, verify your test equipment. Use a **Proving Unit** to confirm that your **Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI)** is functioning correctly. Sixth, perform the act of **Proving Dead**. This involves using the **AVI** to check for voltage between all live conductors and between live conductors and earth at the point of work. Finally, return to the **Proving Unit** and re-verify the **AVI**. This ensures the indicator did not fail during the actual test. 

Think of this like locking your front door before going on holiday. You don't just close the door; you turn the key (Lock-out), pull the handle to make sure it’s caught (Proving Dead), and then check your key is still in your pocket (Re-proving) to ensure the whole process worked as intended. 

*Micro-scenario:* Consider a distribution board where two breakers are labelled 'Sockets'. If you switch off one but do not perform **Proving Dead** at the socket itself, you are relying on a label that may be 20 years old and incorrect.

**Common mistakes**
Learners often confuse **Safe Isolation** with simple switching; **Safe Isolation** is a verified safety process involving locks and testers, whereas simple switching is just the act of turning a device off without security or verification.

Misconceptions (targeted):
- Misconception: Switching off the circuit breaker is enough to start work. | Correction: You must physically lock the device and prove the circuit is dead with a verified indicator. | AC: AC3.7
- Misconception: Any multimeter can be used to check if a circuit is dead. | Correction: Only an **Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI)** should be used, as it is designed to fail-safe and lacks dangerous internal fuses. | AC: AC3.7

**Key Points**
- Identify and isolate the specific supply.
- Secure the isolation with a physical lock and tag (**LOTO**).
- Verify the tool before and after the test using a **Proving Unit**.
- Confirm the absence of voltage between all conductors and earth (**Proving Dead**).

**Quick recap**
Safe isolation is a non-negotiable safety sequence. It moves from identifying the supply to physically locking it off, then verifying the circuit is dead using a three-step 'prove-test-prove' method with an **Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI)** and a **Proving Unit**.

### Coming Up Next
Once the system is safely isolated, we move to the visual inspection phase to check for physical defects before any electrical tests are performed.

questions.hint: Safety rules require the person at risk to have exclusive control of the lock.

questions.questionText: Using your answers to Q1 (nature of isolation), Q2 (verifying indicators), and Q3 (key security), explain how these facts connect to ensure a safe working environment. Why is it necessary to combine all three elements?
keyPoints: Physical security via locks prevents unauthorized re-energisation of the circuit
Verified testing provides evidence that the circuit is actually dead rather than just switched off
Personal control of the key ensures the worker is the only one who can restore power
The system is only safe when it is proven dead and physically secured under the worker's control
expectedAnswer: Safe isolation requires physical security and verified testing to ensure the circuit is dead and cannot be turned back on. By using a Proving Unit to check the indicator and keeping the key themselves, the person performing the work ensures that the 'dead' reading is accurate and that they remain in control of the isolation device at all times.

These facts work together because switching a device off is not enough to guarantee safety. The worker must use a verified indicator to prove the circuit is dead and then apply a lock. Keeping the key ensures that while they are working, no one else can bypass the safety process and re-energise the system.

content.title: Verification Logic & Stop-Triggers
content.content:
### In this lesson
- You will learn why we verify test instruments before and after checking for voltage.
- We will cover the safety rationale for the 'sandwich' test and when you must stop the process.
- Key takeaways include understanding tool reliability and selecting the correct action when safety obstacles occur.

**What this is**
Verification logic refers to the 'prove-dead-reprove' cycle. This involves using a **Proving Unit** to verify an **Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI)** immediately before use, performing the test, and then re-verifying the tool immediately after. This cycle ensures that the tool was working when it gave a 'zero' reading. Stop-triggers are specific conditions, such as an unexpected voltage reading or a broken lock, that require an immediate halt to the procedure for safety reasons.

**Why it matters**
If an **AVI** fails internally (for example, a broken internal wire or a failed LED) while you are testing a live circuit, it will show a 'dead' reading. Without a **Proving Unit**, you would believe the circuit is safe when it is actually lethal. By re-verifying the tool after the test, you prove that the 'zero' reading was because the circuit was dead, not because the tool was broken. This is a safety-critical logic that prevents fatal errors.

**Key facts / rules**
- The **AVI** must be checked against a known source (the **Proving Unit**) both before and after the test.
- A reading of 0V is only valid if the tester is proven functional after the reading is taken.
- If the **AVI** fails to light up on the **Proving Unit** at any stage, the test is invalid.
- Any unexpected voltage reading (e.g., 50V on a supposedly isolated circuit) is a stop-trigger.
- Inability to identify the correct supply or apply a lock is a stop-trigger.
- Never bypass safety steps to save time; the sequence is the protection.

**How to do it**
To apply this logic, start by activating your **Proving Unit** and applying the **AVI** probes to it. Confirm the indicator lights up to its full rated voltage. Next, move to the point of work and perform the check for **Proving Dead**. You must check between Phase and Neutral, Phase and Earth, and Neutral and Earth. If the **AVI** shows no voltage, immediately return to the **Proving Unit** and check the **AVI** again. If it lights up, the circuit is confirmed dead.

If you encounter an obstacle, such as a missing lock-off point or a distribution board that cannot be secured, you must select the correct safety action: stop and escalate. Do not proceed with the work. Similarly, if your **AVI** shows any voltage where there should be none, treat the system as live, stop the procedure, and report the finding to a supervisor. 

Imagine testing a torch before walking into a pitch-black basement. You turn it on outside to make sure it works. You walk through the basement (the test). When you get to the other side, you turn it on again. If it doesn't turn on then, you can't be sure if it was working while you were in the dark, or if you just got lucky. 

*Micro-scenario:* You prove your **AVI** on the **Proving Unit**, and it works. You check the circuit and it shows 0V. You go back to the **Proving Unit**, but now the **AVI** does not light up. In this case, you must assume the circuit is still live and the tester failed mid-way.

**Common mistakes**
Learners often confuse **Proving Dead** with checking for a loss of function in a device; **Proving Dead** is a specific measurement of voltage absence using a verified indicator, whereas checking for loss of function (like seeing if a light is off) does not account for neutral faults or alternative live paths.

Misconceptions (targeted):
- Misconception: If the tester works on the **Proving Unit** first, I don't need to check it again after. | Correction: You must re-prove the tester after the check to ensure it did not fail during the measurement. | AC: AC3.7
- Misconception: If I find a small amount of 'ghost' voltage, it is safe to ignore it. | Correction: Any unexpected reading is a stop-trigger; you must treat the circuit as live and escalate the issue. | AC: AC3.7

**Key Points**
- Proving before ensures the tool is working.
- Proving after ensures the tool *stayed* working during the test.
- Unexpected readings or missing safety equipment are triggers to stop work.
- Escalate any safety concerns to a competent person immediately.

**Quick recap**
The 'prove-test-prove' cycle is the only way to verify that a 'dead' reading is accurate. If the tool fails or the circuit shows unexpected voltage, you must stop immediately and escalate. This logic ensures that your safety is based on evidence, not assumptions.

### Coming Up Next
Now that you understand the logic of proving dead, we will look at the specific physical defects you need to look for during a dead inspection.

questions.questionText: What is the required action if you encounter an unexpected voltage reading during the isolation process?
questions.hint: Unexpected readings indicate the system is not in the safe state you expected.

questions.questionText: Under what specific condition is a reading of 0V considered valid?
questions.hint: A zero reading is only reliable if you know the tool was still working correctly at that moment.

questions.questionText: What does proving the tool again after the test ensure?
questions.hint: This final check confirms the tool did not break during the actual measurement.

questions.questionText: Using your answers to Q1 (unexpected readings), Q2 (validity of 0V), and Q3 (proving after), explain how these facts connect. How do we know that a circuit is truly safe to work on?
keyPoints: A zero reading is only evidence of safety if the tool is verified to be working immediately after the test
Proving the tool after the test confirms it did not fail while checking the circuit
Any voltage reading that is not zero acts as a stop-trigger because it proves the circuit is not isolated
We know the circuit is safe only when the logic of 'prove-test-prove' results in a verified zero reading
expectedAnswer: We know a circuit is safe because the 'prove-test-prove' cycle eliminates the risk of tool failure. If we get a 0V reading, we must re-verify the tester to ensure it stayed working; if it didn't, the test is invalid. Furthermore, any unexpected voltage is a stop-trigger, meaning we must treat the system as live and stop the work immediately.

Safety is confirmed by the logic that a 0V reading is only valid if the tool is proven functional both before and after the check. This ensures the tool was capable of detecting voltage throughout the process. If any voltage is detected when it should be zero, the procedure must stop because the isolation has failed.
questions.hint: Consider how the reliability of the tool affects your interpretation of a 'zero' reading.

content.title: Worked Example: Safe Isolation Procedure
content.given: A technician is required to isolate a single-phase circuit at a distribution board to safely replace a faulty outlet in a workshop.

steps.description: Secure the point of isolation by switching the device to the 'off' position and applying Lock-out Tag-out (LOTO).
steps.result: Circuit is physically locked and tagged

steps.description: Verify the Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI) by testing it against a Proving Unit.
Perform Proving Dead at the point of work by checking for voltage between all live conductors and between live conductors and earth.
Re-verify the AVI on the Proving Unit to ensure the indicator did not fail during the test.
Evaluate the results to confirm the circuit is dead or trigger a stop if any verification failed.

content.notes: Always ensure only the person performing the work holds the key to the lock. Verify the Proving Unit is powered before use.

content.title: Guided Practice: Safe Isolation Logic
content.problem: A technician needs to isolate a lighting circuit in a retail unit. The distribution board is accessible, and the technician has an Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI) and a Proving Unit.

steps.prompt: What physical safety measure must be applied after switching the circuit breaker to the 'off' position?
steps.hint: Think about the mechanical method used to prevent anyone else from turning the power back on.

steps.prompt: Which specific device must be used to verify that the Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI) is working correctly before the test?
steps.hint: This device provides a known voltage source to check your tester.

steps.prompt: What is the name of the specific process of checking for voltage at the point of work using the AVI?
steps.hint: This is the core electrical check in the isolation sequence.

steps.prompt: After testing the circuit and getting a zero reading, what must be done with the AVI immediately?
steps.hint: You need to confirm the tester is still working to trust the zero reading you just saw.

steps.prompt: If the AVI fails to light up on the Proving Unit during the final check, what is the required safety action?
steps.hint: If the tool fails, the test is invalid and you must not proceed.

questions.questionText: In the 'Proving Dead' stage of the sequence, how many specific electrical combinations (checking between conductors and between conductors and earth) must be tested to confirm the absence of voltage?
questions.hint: You must check between Phase-Neutral, Phase-Earth, and Neutral-Earth.

questions.questionText: Explain why a circuit cannot be considered safe if the Approved Voltage Indicator (AVI) fails to light up on the Proving Unit during the final check, even if the circuit itself showed zero volts.
questions.hint: Consider whether the 'zero' reading was caused by a dead circuit or a broken tool.

questions.questionText: A technician is working on a complex system. They have locked the isolator and verified their tester. What is the final action they must take immediately after testing the point of work to complete the verification logic?
questions.hint: This is the final part of the 'sandwich' test (Prove-Test-Prove).

questions.questionText: According to the systematic 'sandwich' verification method, how many times in total must the Proving Unit be used to validate a single isolation procedure?
questions.hint: Think about the checks required before and after the actual test.

questions.questionText: What specific safety procedure uses physical hardware to ensure that only the authorized person performing the work can restore power to the system?
questions.hint: This involves a physical lock and a warning tag.

questions.questionText: Explain the logical connection between the physical locking of a device and the verification of the test instrument. In your answer, include: (1) the specific stage in the sequence where verification occurs, (2) the purpose of the 'sandwich' test, and (3) what must be true about the instrument's state for the isolation to be deemed successful. Why is the final re-proving step considered a non-negotiable part of the sequence logic? (2-3 sentences)
keyPoints: Identifies that verification occurs immediately after physical isolation and locking off
Explains that the 'sandwich' test (prove-test-reprove) ensures instrument reliability
States that the instrument must be confirmed functional both before and after the circuit check
Explains that a failure during the final re-proving step invalidates the previous 'dead' reading
Reasons that without the final check, a tool failure during the test could lead to a false-negative result
expectedAnswer: The verification occurs after the system is locked off but before work begins, using a 'sandwich' test to ensure the instrument did not fail during the 'check for dead' process. For isolation to be successful, the instrument must prove functional against a known source both before and after the circuit test. The final re-proving is non-negotiable because it confirms that a zero-voltage reading was due to a de-energised circuit rather than a sudden equipment malfunction.

Verification happens after physical locking to ensure the specific point of work is safe. The 'sandwich' test confirms the voltage indicator's accuracy; for success, the indicator must show correct operation at both ends of the test cycle. The final re-proving is essential because if the tool fails during the test, the operative might mistakenly believe a live circuit is dead.
questions.hint: Think about how we distinguish between a circuit that has no power and a test tool that has simply stopped working.

questions.questionText: Evaluate how the safe isolation workflow, the verification logic, and stop-triggers integrate to prevent accidents. In your answer, include: (1) the correct sequence of the isolation workflow, (2) the rationale for checking against a known source, (3) the required protocol when encountering unexpected readings, and (4) how these elements collectively mitigate human error. Answer in 3-4 sentences OR concise bullet points.
keyPoints: Outlines the sequence: Identify, Isolate, Lock-off, Prove-Test-Reprove
Explains that checking against a known source removes assumptions about tool functionality
Identifies that unexpected readings act as a 'stop-trigger' requiring immediate cessation of work
Describes how the workflow replaces memory-based checks with a systematic verification cycle
Connects physical security (locks) with logical security (proving dead)
Explains that the protocol ensures safety even if one part of the system (like a breaker or a tool) fails
Maintains that the process is only complete when the final re-proving confirms the tool is still operational
expectedAnswer: The workflow follows a strict sequence of identification, physical locking, and a 'prove-test-reprove' cycle to ensure the system is de-energised. Checking against a known source (proving unit) ensures the indicator is reliable, while any unexpected voltage acts as a stop-trigger to prevent proceeding under unsafe conditions. Together, these steps mitigate human error by requiring objective evidence of safety rather than relying on the perceived state of a switch or breaker.

• The sequence moves from identifying and locking the source to the three-step verification of the circuit.
• Proving against a known source confirms the tool is operational before it is relied upon for safety.
• If unexpected readings occur, the stop-trigger protocol requires the operative to halt and re-evaluate the isolation.
• This integration prevents accidents by ensuring that both physical locks and verified test results confirm a safe working environment.
questions.hint: Consider how the physical act of locking and the logical act of testing provide two different layers of protection.
